title: How to Make a Curtain of Colored Strips for Your Doorframe

steps.headline: Choose the one or two (you can have more if you'd like) colors of colored or tissue paper you are going to use.
steps.description: If using more than one color, choose the pattern and/or arrangement as well.

steps.headline: Cut the tissue or colored paper into inch-thick strips, or whatever seems appropriate for your doorframe.
steps.description: It is important the strips come out even to give it the appearance of being well done.

steps.headline: If the strips are too short, neatly tape them together until reaching the desired length.
steps.description: Four short strips are recommended for a length reaching a little past halfway.

steps.headline: Tape the large strip to the top of the doorframe.
steps.description: Make sure it is firm and will not peel off, fall off, or fall apart once it is walked through. Repeat this process until the whole doorframe is covered.

steps.headline: Choose the paint colors you are going to use.
steps.description: If using more than one color, choose your pattern carefully.

steps.headline: Cut the blank pieces of paper into inch-thick strips, or whatever size is appropriate.
steps.description: Make sure the strips come out even.

steps.headline: Begin painting the strips.
steps.description: Start with your first color if you are using more than one color.

steps.headline: Stop painting once you have gotten four strips, if that is the desired length.
steps.description: Keep on painting for a larger doorframe, and stop earlier for a shorter doorframe.

steps.headline: Tape the painted strips together.
steps.description: If the size seems too short or too long, either remove a strip or paint another one and attach it. If removing a strip, be very careful and gentle as you do so. Not doing this may result in some of the paper being pulled off with the tape.

steps.headline: Tape the large strip to the top of the doorframe.
steps.description: Repeat this process until the doorframe is covered entirely, or leave a small open space if desired.

steps.headline: You are now finished and your curtain is ready to be used!

text: Using Tissue or Colored Paper Choose the one or two (you can have more if you'd like) colors of colored or tissue paper you are going to use. If using more than one color, choose the pattern and/or arrangement as well. Cut the tissue or colored paper into inch-thick strips, or whatever seems appropriate for your doorframe. It is important the strips come out even to give it the appearance of being well done. If the strips are too short, neatly tape them together until reaching the desired length. Four short strips are recommended for a length reaching a little past halfway. Tape the large strip to the top of the doorframe. Make sure it is firm and will not peel off, fall off, or fall apart once it is walked through. Repeat this process until the whole doorframe is covered. Painting the Paper Choose the paint colors you are going to use. If using more than one color, choose your pattern carefully. Cut the blank pieces of paper into inch-thick strips, or whatever size is appropriate. Make sure the strips come out even. Begin painting the strips. Start with your first color if you are using more than one color. Stop painting once you have gotten four strips, if that is the desired length. Keep on painting for a larger doorframe, and stop earlier for a shorter doorframe. Tape the painted strips together. If the size seems too short or too long, either remove a strip or paint another one and attach it. If removing a strip, be very careful and gentle as you do so. Not doing this may result in some of the paper being pulled off with the tape. Tape the large strip to the top of the doorframe. Repeat this process until the doorframe is covered entirely, or leave a small open space if desired. You are now finished and your curtain is ready to be used!
